Bi-functional electrocatalysis through synergetic coupling strategy of atomically dispersed Fe and Co active sites anchored on 3D nitrogen-doped carbon sheets for Zn-air battery Yan Luo a Jie Zhang a Jinwei Chen a b ⁎ Yihan Chen a Chenyang Zhang a Yingjian Luo a Gang Wang a b Ruilin Wang a b ⁎ a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu 610065 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China b Engineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices, Ministry of Education, Chengdu 610065, China Engineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices Ministry of Education Chengdu 610065 China Engineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices, Ministry of Education, Chengdu 610065, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Single atom catalysts (SACs) with unique structure gain much interest in the field of electrocatalysis and show a broad application prospect in long-life rechargeable Zn-air batteries. However, ingenious design and preparation of bi-metal SACs is still difficult to further enhance the bifunctional electrocatalytic activity. Herein, modified zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8/67) was facilely designed to preparation atomically dispersed Fe and Co doping 3D nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets (A-FeCo@NCNs). The Fe or Co single atoms are identified to be coordinated with N atoms and form FeN4, CoN4 or N3Fe-CoN3 anchored on 3D defect carbon, which act as reactive sites for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Through synergetic coupling effect, A-FeCo@NCNs exhibits excellent electrochemical performance with ORR/OER potential gap of 0.80 V. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further indicate the synergistic effect between Fe and Co in A-FeCo@NCNs towards the enhancing ORR activity. The as-prepared catalyst assembled Zn-air battery shows a maximum power density, and superb cycling stability, surpassing that based on commercial Pt/C + IrO2. Results from this study may provide a facile method for precious control of dual-metal single sites doped carbon with highly activity and durability for bifunctional electrocatalysis. Keywords Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks Bi-metal single atoms 3D defective carbon Bi-functional electrocatalysis Zn-air battery 1 Introduction The requirement of global sustainable development for energy and healthy environment impels us to pay more attention on the efficient electrochemical storage and conversion in these vital devices, for instance, metal-air batteries and fuel cells [1,2]. Among these devices, the zinc-air battery is considered to be a viable power source due to the flexible and convenient use, high theoretical energy, environment-friendly and low production cost [3]. Oxygen electrode reactions-oxygen reduction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are involved in ZABs, which contain a multistep proton-coupled electron transfer, thus often showing a kinetically sluggish process [4,5] To satisfy the requirement of both ORR and OER simultaneously, a fine air-electrode should be fabricated in zinc-air battery accordingly [6]. Although precious-metal-based catalysts can efficiently improve the catalytic performance for ORR and OER in a short time, the major drawbacks are scarcity of resource and low long-term stability [7,8]. Obviously, the replacement of precious-metal-based catalysts with noble metal-free catalysts such as metal-nitrogen-carbon materials, transition metal composites and metal-free carbon materials is critical to the extensive application of zinc-air batteries [9,10]. In the previous study, metal-nitrogen-carbon materials with M−Nx (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mn, etc.) coordination have exhibited excellent reactive activity and stability, which could be a promising candidate as bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalysts [11–13]. Most recently, atomically dispersed metal catalysts are widely reported in the field of catalysis, and the performance of the metal-nitrogen-carbon composites are improved by the higher metal utilization and unique coordination structure [14–16]. The activities of SACs are mostly decided by the defined reactive sites and the interaction between the dispersed mental atoms and carbon substrate, which can be solved by the following strategies: (1) modulating the composition by the doping of mental atoms or non-metal atoms to improve the intrinsic activity [17–19]; (2) designing an open porous or other large-area structure to increase the accessibility [5,20]. Fe SACs have been always prepared as ORR catalysts, while they have shown inferior OER performance [21,22]. Therefore, the incorporation of Co catalytic centers with Fe SACs could be a practical approach to promote the ORR and OER performance through synergetic coupling effect [23,24]. The induce of Co will optimize the electronic structure of Fe atoms, which could form new active sites and enhance ORR and OER activity. Thus, the bimetallic Fe-Co single atoms doped nitrogen-carbon could process superior bifunction performance and stability, as compared to the monometallic single atoms doped nitrogen-carbon [25]. Although single atom catalysts (SACs) had been successfully synthesized by different routes some methods such as wet chemistry, defect engineering, wet impregnation and spatial confinement [6,26–28], it still suffers difficult in synthesis of bi-metal SACs. When the bi-metal SACs are synthesized by carbonization of metal organic framework (MOF), the carbon skeleton is prone to collapse and metal atoms tend to agglomerate, which lead a low loading of single atoms and reduce the catalytic activity [27,29]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop a useful method to prepared an atomically dispersed Fe and Co co-doping ORR/OER catalyst, which could be beneficial for the application of bi-metal SACs in the electrochemical devices [27]. Another proposed strategy for improving the electrochemical activity of SACs is to enhance the carbon frameworks with open porous structure. Briefly speaking, 2D carbonaceous materials will expose more reactive area and reduce diffusional resistance, thus the utilization rate of catalytic sites can be significantly improved [11,30]. However, the agglomeration of two-dimensional carbon materials in the preparation of SACs is serious, and the 3D macroporous interconnected carbon matrix constructed by hard template has the advantages of stable structure and faster mass transport, thus leading the zinc-air batteries with durable electrocatalysis and long-term cycling [31–33]. Therefore, it is meaningful to develop convenient approaches for preparing 3D carbon nanosheets with rich atomically dispersed active centers. Based on the aforementioned items, a novel type of 3D nitrogen-doped carbon sheets is designed as substrates for anchoring atomically dispersed Fe and Co reactive centers. The resulting 3D hierarchical catalyst realized the dispersion of the 2D carbon nanosheets, increased the loading of single atoms and enhanced mass transport. Atomically dispersed Fe and Co doping 3D nitrogen-doped carbon sheets (A-FeCo@NCNs) showed a high specific surface area of 809.23 m2g−1 with micro-meso-macropores structure. The 3D nitrogen-doped carbon sheets encapsulated abundant Fe and Co bi-metal single atoms active sites such as FeN4, CoN4 and N3Fe-CoN3. Benefits from the synergetic coupling effect of active sites and unique structure, A-FeCo@NCNs exhibited an excellent bifunction performance: half wave potential (ORRE1/2) of 0.87 V, overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 (OEREj = 10) of 440 mV. The overpotential gap (ΔE) value is 0.80 V, which was smaller than that of integrated Pt/C and IrO2 catalyst couple (ΔE = 0.84 V). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the synergistic effect between Fe and Co would be the key factor. In addition, the A-FeCo@NCNs-assembled air cathode exhibited superb rechargeable Zn-air battery performance, providing with a large power density and specific capacity. The Zn-air battery displayed excellent cycling stability over 500 cycles. Above all, this work demonstrates a promising method for the preparation of atomically dispersed bimetallic sites M−N−C catalyst for the exploration of application of electrocatalysis. 2 Experiment 2.1 Synthesis of silica nanosphere SiO2 nanospheres with an average diameter of 150 nm were prepared by the modified stöber method. In a typical synthesis, 150 mL of EtOH, 60 mL deionized water and 5 mL of aqueous ammonia were firstly mixed in a beaker with magnetic stirring. Then, 5 mL TEOS was dropwise added in the mixture and left for 12 h with vigorous stirring. The colloidal solution was collected by high-speed centrifugation with washing by deionized water and methanol for several times. The obtained SiO2 nanospheres were dispersed in 50 mL of methanol for use. 2.2 Synthesis of SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8/67 10 mL of SiO2 spheres suspension, 1 mL of 20 mM FeCl3⋅6H2O solution, 1 mL of 20 mM Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O solution and 0.98 mM Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O were firstly added into 35 mL of methanol to form a mix solution with string. Then, 0.5 mL NH3⋅H2O was dropwise added in the above solution. After two hours of stirring, the solution was turn to brow, suggesting the formation of hydroxide on the surface of SiO2 spheres with a thin layer. 15 mL of methanol containing 4 mM dimethylimidazole (2-MIM) was added into the above mixture. The solution was continuously stirred at ambient temperature, and 2-MIM was reacted with hydroxide with a slower reaction rate. After 3 h, the final SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8/67 precursor was prepared, the amount of Co2+ and Zn2+ was 0.02 mM and 0.98 mM. In addition, SiO2-Fe-ZIF-8/67 was prepared without adding NH3⋅H2O. 2.3 Synthesis of the A-FeCo@NCNs The SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8/67 precursor was pyrolyzed at 800 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 3 °C min−1 under 5% H2-95% Ar atmosphere. After the furnace cooled down to room temperature naturally, the obtained product was leached in 10% HF for 12 h to get rid of silica template. Then, the final A-FeCo@NCNs was acquired by washing with deionized water and heating at 80 °C in a vacuum. For comparison, NCNs, A-Fe@NCNs, A-FeCo-NC and A-FeCo-NP@NCNs were prepared by pyrolyzing of SiO2@ZIF-8, SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8, Fe-ZIF-8/67 and SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8/67-(0.8/0.2)(0.2 and 0.8 stand for the amount of Co(NO3)2 6H2O and Zn(NO3)2 6H2O), respectively. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 a schematically descripts the synthesis process and the resulting morphology of atomically dispersed Fe and Co doping 3D nitrogen-doped carbon sheets (A-FeCo@NCNs). To begin with, the nano-sized silica spheres (150 nm) were used as the hard template and modified by metal ions (Fig. S1). The various metal ions reacted with NH3·H2O to form hydroxides encased on the surfaces of silica nanospheres. Next, the precursor (SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8/67) was obtained by adding imidazole ligands (Fig. S2) (Zn2+ is complexed with 2-MIM to form ZIF-8, and Co2+ is complexed with 2-MIM to form ZIF-67). By using hydroxides as intermedium could promote the uniform growth of Fe-ZIF-8/67 on the surface of silica nanospheres, and the obtained ZIF nanoparticles are recognized to be 10 nm (Fig. S3a). While SEM image of SiO2-Fe-ZIF-8/67 without adding NH3·H2O shows that Fe-ZIF-8/67 and SiO2 are discrete (Fig. S3b). As compared to SiO2-Fe-ZIF-8/67, SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8/67 shows a uniform core-shell structure, which may be helpful to improve the structure stability and electron conductivity of the final derived product. Finally, 3D hollow sphere hierarchical structure and the resulting catalyst A-FeCo@NCNs were acquired after the process of annealing and removing silica templates. As shown in the SEM imagines of A-FeCo@NCNs (Fig. S4a-b). This unique catalyst is built from interconnected carbon sheets, thus forming a 3D hollow sphere hierarchical structure. The atomically dispersed Fe and Co are anchored on the few-lawyers carbon sheets. However, when Fe-ZIF-8/67 was directly carbonized, the final product A-FeCo-NC showed serious reunion of particles after the uncontrolled pyrolysis process (Fig. S4c-d). It suggests that SiO2 template play an important role in the synthesis of 3D carbon nanosheet structure. Fig. 1b shows the crystalline structure of these as-prepared catalysts. It could be clearly observed that all the samples exhibit only one broad peak with 2θ values of 26°, indexing to the (002) plane of carbon, which implies amorphous structure of the prepared carbon materials [21]. Moreover, no other diffraction peaks are displayed in the patterns, which suggests the absence of the crystalline metals or metal compounds in the catalysts [34]. Also, the broad and weak peaks in the spectra indicates the poor crystallinity of the as-synthesized catalysts, which means the existence of large number of structure defects in the catalysts. And it can be inferred from the XRD pattern (Fig. S5) that Fe and Co were atomically dispersed in A-FeCo-NC. With the increase of Co content, Co nanoparticles were formed integrated with single Fe atom. The diffraction pattern of the A-FeCo-NP@NCNs is indexed to metallic Co with face centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure (PDF#15-0806) [2]. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm of A-FeCo@NCNs was obtained by QUADRASORB SI, and the obtained curves with hysteresis loop are type-IV isotherms in Fig. 1c. The result is consistent with the XRD analysis, suggesting the defective carbon structure of A-FeCo@NCNs with abundant mesoporous [31]. The specific surface area surface of A-FeCo@NCNs was calculated to be 809 m2 g−1. Besides, the pore distribution curve (inset in Fig. 2 c) exhibits a 3D hollow sphere hierarchical structure with numerous mesopores (3.6 nm) and macropores (10–50 nm) in the pyrolytic carbon substrate. And the extensive hierarchical pores are more beneficial to achieve a high content of active centers. As shown in Fig. 2a, the A-FeCo@NCNs exhibits a well-defined macroporous structure with a uniform size of 150 nm. Furthermore, no metal particles could be observed in the imagines, which is consistent with XRD results. Fig. 2b and 2c shows that 3D hollow sphere hierarchical structure is built with nitrogen-carbon sheets derived from Fe-ZIF-8/67@SiO2. A-FeCo@NCNs possesses defective carbon structure with vast mesoporous. High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF)-STEM images (Fig. 2d-f) reveales that many bright dots and dot pair are clearly detected on the carbon matrix. The bright dots shows a narrow size distribution of ~0.25 ± 0.1 nm, confrming the formation of single Fe atom, single Co atom and Fe/Co atomic dual-sites (Fig. 2g). Besides, the content and distribution of elements in A-FeCo@NCNs are shown in Fig. 2g. The surficial elements Fe, Co, C and N are uniformly distributed throughout the whole hollow spheres, which suggestes that the M−Nx moiety may form due to in-situ pyrolysis of Fe-ZF-8/67@SiO2 and subsequent treatment. And inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Table S1) reveales the mental content. Of note, the content of residual Zn atoms in A-FeCo@NCNs is much lower than the content of Fe (0.86 wt%) and Co (1.23 wt%). According to previous studies, ZnNx sites also have the ability to promote ORR but the activity is much lower than that of FeN4 and CoNx [35,36]. Highly dispsersed FeNx and CoNx moieties in A-FeCo@NCNs are the main active sites for ORR/OER. The significant role of Zn species for dispersing Fe and Co atoms is through spacing metal atoms to decrease the probability of aggregation [37]. In contrast, the TEM images of A-FeCo-NP@NCNs exhibites a hollow structure with many nanoparticles. The well-defined lattice fringe dsidtance of about 0.20 nm is indexed to the (111) facet of Co, which is consist with the XRD analysis. Co nanoparticles with a unifom size distrabition of 5 nm are wrapped in graphitic carbon layer (Fig. S6). In order to investegate the types and chemical state of surface elements of the prepared catalysts, XPS spectra are depicted in Fig. 3 . The obtained survey spectra in Fig. S7 shows that the surface elements in NCNs, A-Fe@NCNs and A-FeCo@NCNs consist of C, N, and O. It could be found that Fe is remaining in the A-Fe@NCNs, and A-FeCo@NCNs shows the existence of Fe and Co. Elemental composition obtained from XPS results is showed in Table S2. A-FeCo@NCNs consists of 0.11 wt% Fe and 0.68 wt% Co, which is consistent with the element mapping result. In addition, A-FeCo@NCNs processe the highest nitrogen cotent. Fig. 3a shows the high-resolution C1s XPS spectra of NCNs, A-Fe@NCNs and A-FeCo@NCNs, which can be deconvoluted into C-N (285.8 eV), C-O (288.6 eV), and C-C (284.8 eV). Meanwhile, the fitted high-resolution N1s spectrum classified into several peaks at 405.1, 401.1, 399.7, and 398.5 eV, corresponding to N-O, Fe-N, graphitic-N, pyrrolic-N, and pyridinic-N, respectively (Fig. 3b and S8) [38]. As is known to all, N shows more electro affinity with the metal center, thus the strong reinforcement between metal sites and pyridinic-N can effectively enhance the formation of Fe/Co-Nx reactive sites [9]. Moreover, it could be clearly observed from Table S3 that the content of M−N species in A-FeCo@NCNs is 1.72 wt%, which is much higher than that of A-Fe@NCNs (1.63 wt%). This result indicates that more M−Nx (M = Fe/Co) coordination moieties formed in A-FeCo@NCNs to catalyze ORR and OER. In addition, A-FeCo@NCNs process the highest contents of pyridinic N and graphitic N, which could significantly improve the ORR performance by producing the relatively positive charge on the surrounding carbon atoms, thus enhancing the adsorption of oxygen [39]. The high-resolution spectrum of Fe 2p featured Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p3/2 peaks at 712.2 and 725.1 eV, demonstrating the oxidation state of Fe. Overall, the binding energy of Fe(II) and Fe(III) for A-FeCo@NCNs shows a negative shift, compared with A-Fe@NCNs [12,40]. This is a result of the induction of Co in A-FeCo@NCNs and leading to the interaction between Co and Fe atoms. The electronic structure of metal center has been tuned, thus having greatly affects on the redox potential, the energy of antibonding states, and the oxygen electrocatalytic reaction [21]. Two prominent peaks can be observed in the Co 2p spectra of A-FeCo@NCNs, which are attributed to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 (Fig. 3d). The deconvoluted peaks located at 779.8, and 782.3 eV are assigned to the metallic Co-O and Co-N, suggesting Co active sites are favor for both OER and ORR [31]. In contrast, the Co 2p spectra of A-FeCo-NP@NCNs presents an additional deconvoluted peak of Co0 (776.9 eV), which may due to the accumulation of adjacent Co atoms caused by abundance of Co content, resulting in the production of metallic Co species (Fig. S7-8) [29]. The structural disorder within the prepared catalysts was further identified by Raman analysis. The Raman spectra of NCNs, A-Fe@NCNs and A-FeCo@NCNs present two main peaks at 1357 cm−1 and 1591 cm−1, which are attributed to the amorphous carbon (D band) and graphite carbon (G band), respectively (Fig. 3e and S9) [41–43]. The ID/IG ratio of A-FeCo@NCNs is determined as 1.45, higher than those of NCNs (1.39) and A-Fe@NCNs (1.42). And A-FeCo@NCNs processes abundant defects such as doped defects and porous structure, which are beneficial to electrocatalysis and mass transport. Considering the above results, atomically dispersed Fe and Co anchored on 3D nitrogen-doped carbon sheets has been prepared and the probable chemical bonding in the prepared A-FeCo@NCNs are schematically exhibited in Fig. 3f. The Fe, Co elements may present in the formats of N3Fe-CoN3, CoN4 and FeN4, and the doping N species can exist in graphitic-N, pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N model [25]. The introduction of atomically dispersed Co greatly increases the amount of the formation of additional ORR/OER active sites and turning the electron structure of Fe. The ORR activity of A-FeCo@NCNs were first investegeted by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements in alkaline electrlyte. As exhibited in Fig. 4 (a), the CV curves of catalysts performded in Ar-saturated electrlyte show featureless shapes, while well-defined oxygen reduction peaks emergers in O2-saturated electrolyte, suggesting their electrocatalytic activity towards ORR. The corresponding LSV curves are showed in Fig. 4b and S9. As shown in Fig. 4d, NCNs exhibits inferior ORR activity, and its E1/2 was only 0.74 V, which was much negative than that of A-Fe@NCNs and A-FeCo@NCNs, indicating that highly dispersed FeN4, CoN4 and N3Fe-CoN3 as the main active sites were responsible for the high ORR activity of A-FeCo@NCNs. A-FeCo@NCNs exhibits excellent ORR performance with an onset potential (Eonset) of 1.03 V and a half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.87 V. What’s more, it is still higher by 20 mV than that of Pt/C (E1/2 = 0.85 V). Fig. S10 exhibits the polarization curves of A-FeCo-NC and A-FeCo-NP@NCNs and they are still poorer than that of A-FeCo@NCNs. The ORR performance of the as-prepared catalysts and Pt/C are compared in Table S4. To evaluated the reaction kinetics of catalysts, the Tafel slope was calculated. The Tafel slope of the A-FeCo@NCNs is 98 mV dec−1, which approaches to that of Pt/C (89 mV dec−1), further suggesting a good kinetic process of ORR. Moreover, the reaction kinetics of the A-FeCo@NCNs for ORR were analyzed by RDE measurements under various rotation rates from 400 to 2025 rpm (Fig. 4c). The kinetics-controlled process on A-FeCo@NCNs electrode is confirmed by that the limiting current density in the LSV curves, which increase with increasing rotation speed. The fitted Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots of A-FeCo@NCNs (Fig. 4d) exhibits significant linear relationship, demonstrating the first-order reaction kinetics. The LSV curves and linear corresponding K-L plots for NCNs and A-Fe@NCNs (Fig. S11) also confirm first-order reactions with respect to the dissolved O2. The electron transfer number (n) for A-FeCo@NCNs is calculated to be about 4, indicating an obvious 4e− transfer pathway on the A-FeCo@NCNs electrode. Besides the superior ORR activity, A-FeCo@NCNs also processes excellent long-term stability. A high current retention (98.4%) after 6.5 h measurement is showed in Fig. 4e, while the current response of Pt/C demonstrated a dramatic decrease with 80.3%. Fig. 4f exhibits the Nyquist plots for NCNs, A-Fe@NCNs and A-FeCo@NCNs, and the inset shows the corresponding equivalent circuit, including electrolyte (Rs), constant phase element (Cd), and charge transfer (Rct) components. The A-FeCo@NCNs manifested a smaller (Rct) value, which is lower than those of NCNs and A-Fe@NCNs. This may be ascribed to the inducing of Fe and Co in the N-doping nanosheets, and the low Rct value suggests the faster interfacial electron transfer kinetics on A-FeCo@NCNs electrode and the improved electrocatalytic performance. Then, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was conducted out in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte to study the OER activity of as-prepared catalysts (Figs. 5 a and S12) and the corresponding Tafel plot is shown in Fig. 5b. A-FeCo@NCNs processes superb OER performance compared to those of NCNs, A-Fe@NCNs, A-FeCo-NC and A-FeCo-NP@NCNs. Specifically, A-FeCo@NCNs displays a lower overpotential of 440 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which is more positive than that of state-of-art IrO2 (460 mV). The fitted Tafel plot of A-FeCo@NCNs is 80 mV dec−1, suggesting that the main factor to control the reaction kinetics of OER is first discharge step (i.e., the formation of the OHads intermediate) [6]. The OER performance parameters of different samples are compared in Table S6. To evaluated the long-time durability of catalysts toward OER, chronoamperometry was conducted at a constant potential for 25 h. Compared with IrO2, the A-FeCo@NCNs exhibits a high current density of 9.57 mA cm−2 after continuous testing for the OER. Note that the excellent ORR/OER activity of A-FeCo@NCNs are mainly contributed to FeN4, CoN4 as well as N3FeCoN3. The potential gap (ΔE) between ORR half-wave potential (ORRE1/2 = 0.87 V) and OER overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 (OEREj=10) is usually used to estimate the overall reversible ORR/OER electrocatalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 5a, A-FeCo@NCNs presents the lowest ΔE of 0.80 V, comparing to those of NCNs and A-Fe@NCNs, and 40 mV lower than that of Pt/C + IrO2. The as-prepared A-FeCo@NCN catalyst in this study processes remarkable bifunctional activity and exhibits one of the best values among the reported single atom catalysts (Table S7). The excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic performance can be observed in A-FeCo@NCNs. The proposed ORR and OER mechanism on A-FeCo@NCNs in alkaline solution and schematic illustration of the overall ORR/OER process are exhibited in Fig. 5e and 5f. In conclusion, A-FeCo@NCNs has better ORR performance than A-Fe@NCNs and shows a typical four electron path in alkaline condition from the experiment analysis. The Co modified FeN4 could be the main ORR active sites and undergo following the whole cycle [20]. Four electrons are consumed in each cycle, producing 4OH− rather than 2H2O2. In addition, during the OER process, a four electron transfer steps are thermodynamically conducted on the Fe modified CoN4 involving a series of intermediates (e. g. *OH, *O and *OOH) [29,44]. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation studies were performed to explore the role of Co dopants and the synergistic effect between FeN4 and CoN4 for ORR [45–47]. The computational details are presented in Supporting Information and structure models were established (Fig. 6 a). The A-FeCo@NCNs was used to study the effect of Co atom dopants in FeN4. In comparison, A-Fe@NCNs is obtained without introducing Co element and A-FeCo-NP@NCNs is built with Co metallic nanoparticles adjacent to FeN4. The differential charge density distributions of those structural models are showed in Figs. 6b and S13. Moreover, the Bader charge for metal atoms in FeN4, FeN4-CoN4, and FeN4-Co structures (Fig. S14) was obtained. Of note, the metal atoms (both Fe and Co) are electron donors, while the adjacent C/N atoms are electron acceptors. Fe atom in FeN4 loses 1.052 electrons, while Fe atom in FeN4-CoN4 loses 1.048 electrons, which indicates the increased electron density around Fe atom in FeN4-CoN4, agreeing well with the XPS results [48,49]. It is known that that higher electron density would be favorable for the adsorption and activation of O2 molecules and the high ORR activities of Fe single atom catalysts are mainly contributed by the enhanced electron density around Fe atoms [50]. Based on these results, it can be deduced that Fe and Co in the carbon framework will affect each electronic structure. Moreover, such synergetic effect will improve the activity towards ORR. The association pathway for the ORR was favored on FeN4, Fe4Co4, and FeN4-Co structures (Figs. 6c and S15). Fig. 6(d-f) shows the free energy diagram of ORR process on the three models at zero electrode potential (U = 0 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)), the equilibrium potential (U = 1.23 V) and the thermodynamic limiting potential for which all elementary reaction become energetically negative. All steps are exothermic at U = 0 V. And as U increased, the elementary step is less exothermic. When the thermodynamic limiting potential is more approach to 1.23 V, the higher activity will be shown. FeN4-CoN4 shows a larger thermodynamic limiting potential (0.85 V) than those of Fe in FeN4 (0.820 V) or Fe in FeN4-Co (0.81 V). It can be concluded that FeN4-CoN4 has higher ORR activity than FeN4 and FeN4-Co, which can be elaborated as a synergistic effect between Fe and Co in A-FeCo@NCNs. This result is in agreement with our experimental dates that A-FeCo@NCNs shows better ORR activity than A-Fe@NCNs and A-FeCo-NP@NCNs. Thus, the results suggest that A-FeCo@NCNs show higher activity and the synergistic effect between Fe and Co will be the key factor. The outstanding ORR and OER performance of A-FeCo@NCNs could attributed to several factors. Firstly, atomically dispersed of Fe and Co was prepared by a facile method, which could provide more active sites with synergetic coupling effect for the electrochemical reactions. Secondly, high N-doping level are achieved which could modulate the electronic properties of metal atoms and combine metal atoms to form rich defects in carbon nanosheets [17]. Thirdly, the interaction between mental atoms provides Co modified FeN4 and Fe modified CoN4, which optimizes both ORR and OER paths [20]. Finally, the hollow structure can increase the number of accessible active sites and nanosheet structures can promote electron transfer and mass transfer. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the rechargeable Zn-air battery was assembled by appling the A-FeCo@NCNs as the air electrode to evaluate the practical performance in primary Zn-air batteries (ZABs). Fig. S16 shows the Open-circuit voltage curves of Zn-air battery with A-FeCo@NCNs and Pt/C + IrO2 mixture (mass ratio = 1:1). The A-FeCo@NCNs-based ZAB exhibits a sable potential platform of 1.46 V, which is little higher than that of 20% Pt/C + IrO2 (1.43 V). The result is consistent with OCP acquired by voltmeter. As exhibited in Fig. 7b, the galvanostatic discharge curves of ZABs were performed with a constant current density of 10 mA cm−2. A-FeCo@NCNs-based ZAB shows a specific capacity of 736.2 mAh g−1 Zn and energy capacity of 890.5 mWh g−1 Zn, while the specific capacity and energy capacity of battery equipped with Pt/C + IrO2 are 651.7 mAh g−1 Zn and 759.2 mWh g−1 Zn. Furthermore, the rate performance of A-FeCo@NCNs-based ZAB was studied at different current densities from 10 mA cm−2 to 40 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7c). The voltage of the A-FeCo@NCNs-based ZAB is higher than that of Pt/C + IrO2. The discharging/charging curves and power density profiles are displayed in Fig. 7d. And the A-FeCo@NCNs-based ZAB exhibits an excellent power density of 132 mW cm−2, as compared to those of some relevant catalysts reported recently (Table S5). Fig. 7e shows the long-life galvanostatic discharging-charging cycle performance of A-FeCo@NCNs. The round-trip efficiency of A-FeCo@NCNs-based ZAB is higher than that of Pt/C + IrO2-based ZAB during the discharging/charging process, suggesting a better rechargeable capability of battery employing A-FeCo@NCNs. And A-FeCo@NCNs-based ZAB shows outstanding stability with higher round-trip efficiency of 60.27% after 500 cycles. While the round-trip efficiency commercial Pt/C + IrO2-based ZAB is drop from can reach 57.2% to 53.7% after 300 cycles. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, atomically dispersed Fe and Co doping 3D nitrogen-doped carbon sheets (A-FeCo@NCNs) was prepared by a highly facile and effective approach. By precisely control the structure and component of the precursor, the resulting electrocatalysts processes open porous structure and abundant single atom sites after confined pyrolysis. The uniform distribution of metal and nitrogen within the defected carbon lattices promise the formation of M−Nx moiety. The electronic interaction between metals atoms makes the Co modified FeN4 and Fe modified CoN4 as the efficient ORR and OER sites, respectively. Expectedly, the synergetic coupling strategy is accounted for the enhanced ORR by DFT calculations. In addition, the outstanding stability of A-FeCo@NCNs ensures the practical application of the catalyst. When employed A-FeCo@NCNs as the oxygen electrode of Zn-air battery, the battery shows higher specific capacity, larger power density and better rechargeability as compared to commercial Pt/C + IrO2-based ZAB. This work offers a new avenue for the fabrication of bi-metal SACs with broad application prospects in oxygen electrocatalysis for rechargeable metal-air battery and other sustainable energy devices. coredata.dc:description: Single atom catalysts (SACs) with unique structure gain much interest in the field of electrocatalysis and show a broad application prospect in long-life rechargeable Zn-air batteries. However, ingenious design and preparation of bi-metal SACs is still difficult to further enhance the bifunctional electrocatalytic activity. Herein, modified zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (SiO2@Fe-ZIF-8/67) was facilely designed to preparation atomically dispersed Fe and Co doping 3D nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets (A-FeCo@NCNs). The Fe or Co single atoms are identified to be coordinated with N atoms and form FeN4, CoN4 or N3Fe-CoN3 anchored on 3D defect carbon, which act as reactive sites for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Through synergetic coupling effect, A-FeCo@NCNs exhibits excellent electrochemical performance with ORR/OER potential gap of 0.80 V. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further indicate the synergistic effect between Fe and Co in A-FeCo@NCNs towards the enhancing ORR activity. The as-prepared catalyst assembled Zn-air battery shows a maximum power density, and superb cycling stability, surpassing that based on commercial Pt/C + IrO2. Results from this study may provide a facile method for precious control of dual-metal single sites doped carbon with highly activity and durability for bifunctional electrocatalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Bi-functional electrocatalysis through synergetic coupling strategy of atomically dispersed Fe and Co active sites anchored on 3D nitrogen-doped carbon sheets for Zn-air battery
